data.text:
Are you a fan of Pedro Ortiz de Pinedo’s works? Look no further as we gather all the latest movies featuring this talented actor in one place. From action to romance, experience his versatility and on-screen charisma as we take you through a roundup of Pedro Ortiz de Pinedo’s movies. Get ready to be entertained!

As an Amazon Associate I earn from qualifying purchases.

1. Las golfas (1969)

“Las golfas” (1969) is a zany Mexican comedy directed by Fernando Cortés, with an all-star cast including Isela Vega, Gilda Mirós, and Gina Romand. When the prostitute Diana is kicked out of the establishment she worked at, she finds refuge in the home of Luis, a man with no vested interest.

2. Los juniors (1970)

In the 1970 film “Los juniors, “ we witness the life-altering friendship between three young men as they navigate their rebellious journey through the intricacies of womanhood, drug addiction, and intense emotions. Set against the backdrop of Mexico, these spirited friends embark on a series of hilarious, heartfelt, and adventurous escapades that test the limits of their bonds while shaping an unforgettable tale of camaraderie and self-discovery. Don’t miss out on the laughter and raw emotion as our unlikely heroes take on the challenges of life in “Los juniors. “.

3. Los Beverly de Peralvillo (1971)

“Los Beverly de Peralvillo, “ a 1971 Mexican comedy film, follows El Borras, a struggling taxi driver, and his devoted wife as they juggle their life with an extended family. El Borras’ wife, who is heavily influenced by her mother, insists on inviting relatives to live with them in an effort to help her family.

4. El sinvergüenza (1971)

“El sinvergüenza, “ a 1971 Mexican comedy by José Díaz Morales, delves into the world of extreme gambling and its consequences. When a passionate gambler loses everything, he must resort to the unconventional and humorous methods of earning a living. The film, with its lighthearted approach to life’s challenges, showcases the undeniable charm of Mauricio Garcés, Paula Cusi, and Yolanda Rigel in their respective roles.

5. Secreto de confesión (1971)

Secreto de confesión takes audiences into a poignant drama centered around María, a nurse from a loving but complex family. María’s father is a smuggler, while her mother is a nurse, and her half-brother and half-sister both work in the same profession. In a world of secrets and unspoken feelings, María finds herself in a complicated situation when she falls in love with a journalist investigating her father’s illicit activities.

6. ¡Qué familia tan cotorra! (1973)

¡Qué familia tan cotorra! is a heartwarming comedy-drama that takes viewers on a journey through the ups and downs of family life. Set in 1973, the movie follows the story of El Borras, a taxi driver, and La Pecas as they eagerly anticipate their first child, while El Abuelo’s mother and his half-brother move in with them. As the family grows bigger and dynamics shift, it leads to unexpected hilarity and heartfelt moments that will keep viewers captivated.

7. Gavilán o paloma (1985)

Gavilán o paloma is a gripping Mexican drama film released in 1985, directed by Alfredo Gurrola and written by Fernando Galiana. The movie is based on the life of José José, a Mexican singer known for his incredible rise to stardom in the music industry. The film takes us through José José’s triumphs, setbacks, and the various ups and downs faced due to his excessive drinking and love of alcohol.

9. Mentiras (1986)

“Mentiras, “ Mexican drama from 1986, tells the story of a young woman who discovers her husband’s darkest secrets. Directed by Abel Salazar and Alberto Mariscal, this film is a compelling exploration of truth, love, and betrayal. Running for a total of 1 hour and 40 minutes, “Mentiras” stars Lupita D’Alessio, Juan Ferrara, and Jorge Ortiz de Pinedo.

13. Sabor a mí (1988)

“Sabor a mí, “ released in 1988, unfurls the compelling life of renowned Mexican composer Álvaro Carrillo Morales, the mastermind behind the chart-topper ‘Sabor a mi. ‘ This dramatic exploration delves into the highs and lows of the composer’s journey to fame, unveiling not just his musical genius but also his personal struggles and triumphs. Directed by René Cardona Jr.

14. El gran relajo mexicano (1988)

“El gran relajo mexicano” is a delightful 1988 comedy-drama film that will have you laughing and crying in delight. Written and directed by Alfredo B. Crevenna with contributions from Raúl Ramírez, this film captures the essence of Mexican culture and traditions. Set against the picturesque backdrop of Mexico, the story follows a group of colorful and unforgettable characters as they navigate through life’s ups and downs.

15. Cándido Pérez, especialista en señoras (1991)

In the 1991 comedy, “Cándido Pérez, especialista en señoras, “ viewers will laugh along as Cándido Pérez, a charming and dashing man, excels in his profession as a specialist in working with women. This uproarious film showcases the comedic exploits of Cándido Pérez, played by Jorge Ortiz de Pinedo, and the beautiful and talented actresses Nuria Bages and Alejandra Meyer as they navigate the humorous world of matchmaking, seduction, and romance. With a colorful assortment of characters and delightful twists, “Cándido Pérez, especialista en señoras” is a must-watch for fans of comedy, romance, and heartfelt humor.
